sen.j: 坂上当道（さかのうえ の まさみち）は、坂上氏の一族の人物。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Masamichi is one of the Sakanoue clan people.

sen.j: 坂上田村麻呂の孫であり、「坂上氏系図」は坂上浄野の子と、「文徳実録」は坂上広野の子と伝えている。
sen.e: Masamichi is the grandson of SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro (a military man of the early Heian period), and the son of SAKANOUE no Kiyono according to 'Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan', but is written as the son of SAKANOUE no Hirono in 'Montoku Jitsuroku' (fifth of the six official national history books).

sen.j: 田村麻呂の長男の坂上大野も次男の広野も早世したため三男の浄野が坂上氏の家督を嗣ぎ、その後を当道が嗣ぐ。
sen.e: Since Tamuramaro's eldest son SAKANOUE no Ono, and his second son SAKANOUE no Hirono both died young, the headship of the family was handed over to the third son Kiyono, and then to Masamichi.

sen.j: 当道の子の坂上好蔭は曾祖父の田村麻呂以来の東北経営に従事し、武人として活躍し従四位上、右近少将になった。
sen.e: Masamichi's son SAKANOUE no Yoshikage was engaged in the management of the Tohoku region which had continued since the time of his grandfather Tamuramaro, and, making a spectacular showing as a warrior, became Jushiinojo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) Ukon no shosho (Minor Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards).

sen.j: しかし、孫の坂上是則や曾孫の坂上望城は都に住し、歌人として名を残しており、当道の子孫は検非違使大尉や明法博士など法律に関する分野で活躍した。
sen.e: However, Masamichi's grandson SAKANOUE no Korenori and his great-grandson SAKANOUE no Mochiki lived in the capital and left a name as a poet, and a number of Masamichi's descendants actively engaged themselves in the law-related jobs such as Kebiishi no taijo (a Kebiishi police officer) and Myoho hakase (a professor of law).

sen.cmt: their names as poets と修正しました。後半部分を文脈に応じて修正しました。
sen.e: However, Masamichi's grandson SAKANOUE no Korenori and his great-grandson SAKANOUE no Mochiki lived in the capital and left their names as poets, and a number of Masamichi's descendants took active roles in the law-related field such as Kebiishi no taijo (a Kebiishi police officer) and Myoho hakase (a professor of law).

sen.j: 一方、当道は、父あるいは伯父の広野以来の坂上氏の重要な拠点でもある摂津国住吉郡平野庄（大阪市平野区）の経営にも従事していたようである。
sen.e: Meanwhile, it appears Masamichi was engaged also in the management of Hiranosho (present Hirano Ward, Osaka City) in Sumiyoshi-gun of Settsu Province (partly Osaka Prefecture, and partly Hyogo Prefecture) which had been an important domain for the Sakanoue clan since the time of his father or of his uncle Hirono.

sen.j: 同地の杭全神社などの伝承によれば、当道は「坂上広野を開発領主とする摂津国平野庄に住し広野の後の平野の坂上氏の家督を継ぎ、素盞嗚尊を勧請し祇園社（現在の杭全神社）を創建した」とされる。
sen.e: According to a legend handed down in Kumata-jinja Shrine and the like in the area, Masamichi "lived in Hiranosho of Settsu Province, its kaihatsu ryoshu (a local notable who actually developed the land) being SAKANOUE no Hirono, where he succeeded to the property of the SAKANOUE clan after Hirono and established Gion-sha Shrine (present Kumata-jinja Shrine) enshrining Susanoo no mikoto (the son of Izanagi no mikoto and Izanami no mikoto, and younger brother to Amaterasu oomikami, the Sun Goddess)."

sen.j: 中世に平野庄の坂上氏の後裔として登場する平野氏は、当道の系統ではなく、広野の子の坂上峯雄（侍従）、孫の坂上峯盆（清水寺別当、出羽権介）、曾孫の坂上行松（行増、秋田城介権守）の流れを汲むと伝えている。
sen.e: It is said that the Hirano clan which appears in the medieval period as an offspring of the Sakanoue clan is not descended from Masamichi but from Hirono's son SAKANOUE no Mineo (Chamberlain), his grandson SAKANOUE no 峯盆 (Kiyomizu-dera betto [Chief Priest at Kiyomizu-dera Temple] and Dewa no Gon no Suke [provisional vice governor of Dewa Province (Yamagata and Akita Prefectures)]), and his great-grandson SAKANOUE no Yukimatsu (his first name could be Yukimasu)(Akita-jo no suke gonnokami [provincial governor of Akita-jo castle, and provisional governor of Dewa Province).
sen.cmt: 峯雄、峯盆、行松、行増はそれぞれ読み方不明です（ローマ字表記は用語集から）。また「秋田城介権守」の形では意味不明で用語集にも見当たりません。一応「城介」「権守」のそれぞれの意味と峯盆が出羽権介であったことからの類推でprovincial governor of Akita-jo castle, and provisional governor of Dewa Provinceと訳出しましたが、あくまでも仮訳です。
